'''''Alloclavaria purpurea''''' is a [[coral fungus]] commonly known as the '''purple coral''', or the '''purple fairy club'''. Formerly known as ''Clavaria purpurea'', it has been moved to its own [[genus]] as a result of [[phylogenetic]] analysis.<ref name="pmid17256578">{{cite journal |author=Dentinger BT, McLaughlin DJ. |title=Reconstructing the Clavariaceae using nuclear large subunit rDNA sequences and a new genus segregated from ''Clavaria'' |journal=[[Mycologia]] |volume=98 |issue=5 |pages=746–62 |year=2006 |pmid=17256578 |doi= 10.3852/mycologia.98.5.746|url=}}</ref>

==Description==
The fruiting body of ''Alloclavaria purpurea'' is made of numerous slender cylindrical spindles that may grow to a height of {{convert|12|cm|in}}, with individual spindles being 2–6 millimeters thick. The color is purple or lavender, although the color fades in older specimens. The [[spore print]] is white. It is reported to be edible.<ref name="isbn1-55407-115-1">{{cite book
 |last=Phillips
 |first=Roger
 |title=Mushrooms & other fungi of North America
 |publisher=Firefly Books
 |location=Buffalo
 |year=2005
 |pages=
 |isbn=978-1-55407-115-9
 |oclc=60318881
}}</ref> Fruit bodies are found in [[spruce-fir forests]].<ref name="urlwww.for.gov.bc.ca">{{cite web |url=http://www.for.gov.bc.ca/hfd/library/FIA/2008/FSP_Y082052a.pdf |title=www.for.gov.bc.ca |format= |work= |accessdate=2008-11-10}}</ref>
